At length the animal functions begin to fail—the mind 〈◊〉 by no cauſe, at leaſt by that which is extremely ſlight, to 〈◊〉 , anxieties, ſorrow, anger, fear—becomes incompetent 〈◊〉 to vain and perverſe imaginations—the power of 〈◊〉 dies away, and reaſon fails—ſleep is diſturbed, turbulent, 〈◊〉 replete with terror—in the breaſt great ſtraitneſs, 〈◊〉 —violent difficulty of breathing, joined ſometimes with 〈◊〉 of the cheſt—tremblings and palpitations of the heart 〈◊〉 .

Now, from theſe ſymptoms, it appears very obvious, that 〈◊〉 diſeaſe is a nervous affection like the former, though we 〈◊〉 this to be ſomewhat different, and to depend more 〈◊〉 a torpidity of the nervous ſyſtem, than too great an incitability; and have the local incitability manifeſted in different 〈◊〉 , brought on from the continuance of the complaint.

For we muſt obſerve, in its commencement the ſigns of great torpor only make their appearance—beſides, the diſeaſe ſeldom appears early in life, and more uſually in thoſe advanced in years
only, and is apt to attack thoſe who lead indolent and ſedentary lives, are much addicted to ſtudy, and deep thinking, and oppreſſed with thoſe particular mental affections I have called ſaturnine, (79.) for theſe are apt to weaken and blunt the active powers of the conſtitution, render the circulation and nervous influence weak and ſluggiſh—and, indeed, ſome medical writers have almoſt wholly attributed this diſeaſe to a ſtate of mental affections. Beſides, their ſymptoms in winter, autumn, or any cold weather, are always more violent—but, on the contrary, in warm, and in the ſummer ſeaſon, hypochondriacs are more alert and vigorous; and in women afflicted with this diſeaſe, it is always increaſed at the time their menſes ought to flow; for they, 〈◊〉 the moſt part, labour under ſome defect in this point—add to this, hypochondriacs can very rarely be affected with continued, epidemic, or infectious fevers—to the plague though they are liable—ſtill remain free from many other diſeaſes which reign at particular times; for, from the torpid ſtate of th ••
•••
vous ſyſtem, the nerves become incapable of feeling the 〈◊〉 of the morbid particles which get into the habit, and 〈◊〉 theſe particles are permitted to paſs through the machine 〈◊〉 creating any diſturbance—the ſame happens to the 〈◊〉 , but not to hyſteric people.

CAUSES. The remote or inducing are, beſides thoſe 〈◊〉 above, too long continued watching—hard drinking—regular diet—natural prediſpoſition—or whatever may 〈◊〉 to nervous diſorders in general in ſuch conſtitutions.

CHARACTERISTIC SIGNS. An affection ariſing from too torpid a ſtate of the nervous, and want of proper irritability of the vaſcular ſyſtem, attended with languor, ſadneſs, and 〈◊〉 from inadequate cauſes, affections of the bowels and ſtomach, and mental deſpondency.

CURE. Our remedies muſt be of two kinds, corporeal and mental; for our indications are, to remove the affections of the ſtomach and bowels, increaſe nervous incitability, and 〈◊〉 irritability, and properly regulate the laſt, and alleviate the diſtreſs and uneaſineſs of the mind.

As little can be expected towards performing a radical 〈◊〉 , when the diſeaſe is once fixed, as it very often originates 〈◊〉 the very formation of the conſtitution, and depends ſo much 〈◊〉 the ſtate of the mind, we muſt attend to ſuch things as 〈◊〉
••
leviate bodily diſtreſs, ſo that no imperfection in any part of the machine ſhall contribute to increaſe the uneaſy ſymptoms.

It is therefore firſt adviſeable to unload the inteſtines, with a glyſter, or ſome aloetic medicine, (No. 108.) after having procured
two or three copious evacuations, then let the ſtomach be 〈◊〉 with a vomit, (No. 11, 12.) either will anſwer the purpoſe, or white vitriol, (168.) if acidities prevail in the ſtomach, they ſhould be corrected with alkaline ſalts, (191.) chalk, &c. ( 〈◊〉 .) (No. 42, 43.) particularly calcined magneſia, or ſpirit of 〈◊〉 ammoniac with quicklime, as they unite with acid, 〈◊〉 fermentation and creating any wind; and in this caſe 〈◊〉 vegetables, (190.) ſhould be avoided—though leavened 〈◊〉 and vinegar may be taken with animal food, as the leaſt 〈◊〉 ; for ſolely it could not be perſiſted in, without 〈◊〉 to corrupt the ſtate of the blood, (74.) teſtaceous 〈◊〉 , or ſhell-fiſh, (177.) are proper viands with this intent—if 〈◊〉 want to contribute to keep the body open by abſorbents, the vegetable alkali, (191.) or magneſia, muſt be employed—if that of unneceſſary, or a check is to be given to any evacuation of the 〈◊〉 by theſe means, chalk, crabs eyes, or other ſimilar 〈◊〉 , (191.) or the volatile alkali, (191.) muſt be exhibited 〈◊〉 any of which though muſt be employed in ſuch quantities 〈◊〉 totally to deſtroy the acid neceſſary for the compoſition of animal fluids for the purpoſe of nouriſhment.

In caſes of coſtiveneſs, we ſhould confine ourſelves to ſmall 〈◊〉 of the aloetic pill occaſionally, (No. 108) ſuch as will 〈◊〉 keep the body open; for theſe after the operation, are 〈◊〉 apt to leave the body in a coſtive ſtate—rhubarb, therefore, 〈◊〉 be avoided, and the common ſaline purgatives joined with antimonials—after theſe things are effected, we muſt conſider 〈◊〉 are likely to prevent a return of the ſymptoms.

Should the ſtomach be relaxed, as is ſometimes the caſe, though 〈◊〉 always, we muſt endeavour to give it increaſe of power, by 〈◊〉 and ſtrengthening applications, as the vitriolic acid, at that of ſea ſalt—alſo tar water, fixed ſal ammoniac, or water 〈◊〉 ammonia; theſe are ſaid to ſtimulate the ſtomach, 〈◊〉 often increaſe the appetite—in this diſeaſe the fixed ammonical ſalt has been of ſingular efficacy, by the daily uſe of it in 〈◊〉 , juſt what would render the bowels lax—after taking it ſix, eight, or twelve months, the cold bath has completed the cure— 〈◊〉 , as cinnamon, ginger, pepper, nutmegs, cloves, and other ſubſtances poſſeſſed of certain degrees of pungency; theſe 〈◊〉 extremely uſeful, particularly if the ſtomach is very torpid, 〈◊〉 much relaxed—they fit that organ for feeling the effect of 〈◊〉 medicines, as well as increaſe its temporary action—on which account, volatile ſalts of hartſhorn, or ammonia prepared, are well calculated, and with tonics are very properly conjoined—bitters alſo are very uſeful, as quaſſia wood, columbo, orange
•••• , gentian, chamomile, &c. and their preparations, either in
infuſion, tincture, powder, or extract—but we muſt not perſiſt in the uſe of any of theſe too long, leſt they ſhould hurt the tone of the ſtomach by their long continuance, which they art apt to do.

Bitters and aſtringents united are ſaid to have more efficacy than either ſeparately—bark, therefore, as poſſeſſing theſe properties, has been highly extolled; but the ſame caution is • ere neceſſary, 〈◊〉 the ſame reaſons.

The beſt remedy for producing the deſired purpoſe in this caſe, and what may be continued the longeſt with the greateſt ſafety, in iron, and its preparations—the ſteel waters have been recommended, and often proved ſucceſsful—but on theſe Dr. CULLEN makes, though a minute, a very judicious remark, and ſays, though in the hypochondriac diſeaſe chalybeate waters have ſometimes been apparently efficacious, he imputes it more to the amuſement and exerciſe accompanying the drinking them at the fountain head, rather than to the tonic power of the ſmall quantity of iron they maintain—perhaps the elementary water favouring the excretions may have a ſhare in alleviating the diſeaſe—and it is for the ſame reaſon, probably, that theſe people are relieved more by drinking tea and coffee than thoſe who labour merely 〈◊〉 indigeſtion, and alſo why the warm bath is preferred to the cold in the former caſe, and in the latter prohibited.

If the mind is haraſſed, or in pain, and flatulence, attended with head-ach, a ſlight opiate, joined with a cordial volat ••• draught, may be given, at from five to ten drops of tincture of opium, with five or ſix grains of ſalt of hartſhorn, in a little peppermint water, may be given; but opiates ſhould be very ſparingly uſed—in ſpaſmodic affections they may be uſed alſo in the ſame manner, coupled with aſafoetida or muſk—if the pulſe ſhould be quick, and there ſhould be a perceptible feveriſhneſs, aromatics and ſteel muſt be omitted, and exchanged for bark and the vitriolic acid.

We ſhould be particularly careful that the patient ſhould be thrown into ſuch ſituations, as to keep his mind in a ſtate of cheerfulneſs, in order to its being drawn from thoſe unpleaſant reflections by which it is diſturbed, particularly ſuch as lead him 〈◊〉 blood over what he conſiders an irremediable calamity, his ill ſtate of health—leſſons of philoſophy and reaſon are of little uſe, if any, it is momentary: for the firſt eructation or pain, however trifling, overturns the ſtrongeſt arguments that can have been advanced, and he reverts back to his uſual deſpondency—nor can patients of this ſort bear raillery, not any thing is to them ſo offenſive, they conſider it either as ignorance, or
the want of humanity, and will form moſt unconquerable diſlikes to thoſe who uſe it.

Cheerful company will be found always beneficial, and any exerciſe in the open air that requires dexterity, for theſe amuſe the mind—as to exerciſe, riding on horſeback, or driving a carriage, is the moſt eligible; but, if it can be afforded, taking a long journey, or going from one watery place to another, claims the preference; for variety of objects are perpetually engaging the attention, few of ſettled diſguſt are preſenting themſelves; and conſtant exerciſe employs a good deal of his time, and ſteals 〈◊〉 as it were from himſelf; and by theſe means he will lead at leaſt a life of comfortable ſatisfaction, fancying the whole 〈◊〉 he has derived from change of air, which will encourage 〈◊〉 in the purſuit; in fine, whatever is directed to him ſhould be capable of furniſhing amuſement, and never carried to exceſs; the fatigue of every ſort is extremely detrimental—his diet ſhould be light, ſit eaſy on the ſtomach, agreeable to the palate, cordial, nouriſhing, and eaſy of digeſtion—animal food is in general 〈◊〉 moſt proper—and his drink ſhould be ſpirits, which he likes 〈◊〉 , lowered with water.

I have, in the courſe of practice, met with ſome caſes extremely perplexing, where ſymptoms declaratory of both hyſteric and hypochondriac affections manifeſted themſelves—hence I have 〈◊〉 to call it the

div.head: § 7. HYSTERIA-HYPOCHONDRIAC DISEASE,
div.p: 〈◊〉 participating both of one and the other, which, as it has occurred to me, I ſhall take the liberty to deſcribe.

DESCRIPTION. In this complaint patients chiefly complain of heavy, uneaſy pains in the head, ſometimes fugitive 〈◊〉 acute—a dimneſs of ſight; but this temporary, a ſenſe of ••• gulation, ringing in the ears, and quickneſs of hearing— 〈◊〉 ſtarting at any ſlight noiſe, on the opening of a door quickly, or any thing falling in the room—ſometimes they have complained of a coldneſs of the head, particularly the back part, 〈◊〉 water was trickling down it—flatulence of the ſtomach and 〈◊〉 —ſometimes they are coſtive, now and then otherwiſe—wine is made frequently, in ſmall quantity, then becomes turpid; at other times more copious, and of an amber colour, 〈◊〉 or never purely limpid—they oftentimes complain of an 〈◊〉 , tingling, or pricking in the ſkin, eſpecially if a gentle 〈◊〉 is promoted—ſometimes an eruption like the nettle-raſh •• ews itſelf—frequently a general tumefaction, of a puffy aſpect, without any ſpots—at others very ſmall veſicular eruptions at the
tips of the fingers; and all theſe external appearances are, for the moſt part, attended with great heat, itching, or a ſenſe 〈◊〉 pricking—the appetite is very irregular—the mind eaſily diſturbed, and generally brooding over ſome perſonal calamity, chiefly imaginary—the circulation ſluggiſh and languid—the pulſe ſlow—and the extremities, for the moſt part, cold.

CAUSES. Theſe appearances I always ſuſpect from ſome acrimony ſubſiſting in the fluids, and thus far practice 〈◊〉 confirmed my opinion, enables me to reaſon on theſe appearances, and reconcile them to the doctrines laid down.

For the incitability of the nervous ſyſtem ſeems to have been kept by the ſtimulus of the acrimonious humours, which was not ſufficiently powerful to increaſe properly the action of 〈◊〉 vaſcular ſyſtem—hence the internal parts would be loaded, and the acrid particles have a power of exerting their ſtimulus 〈◊〉 proportion to the quantity retained—beſides, from the torpid ſtate of the circulation, the acrimony would be greatly increaſed by the retention of ſuch materials as ſhould naturally have been thrown out of the habit; and this I am warranted to 〈◊〉 from what occurred on any eruption appearing on the 〈…〉 hot tumefaction of the extremities, or by gentle ſweat being promoted; for at that time the patients were more conſiderably relieved.

CHARACTERISTIC SIGNS. Quick nervous incit • bi •••• , united with ſtrong mental prepoſſeſſion, and perſuaſion, of the patient's own miſery, and fatality of their ſituation, with torpor of the vaſcular ſyſtem.

CURE. The indications are, to render the nervous influence more equable, and take off the vaſcular torpidity; and theſe are chiefly accompliſhed by cordials, aromatics, and ſtimulating antiſpaſmodics, by promoting a determination of the fluids to the ſurface.

But, notwithſtanding gentle perſpiration is not ſingularly 〈◊〉 , for this purpoſe antimonials muſt not be exhibited, 〈◊〉 muſt opiates for alleviating ſpaſmodic affections, for they very often do infinite miſchief, by relaxing the ſtomach, and inc ••••
ing the torpor of the ſyſtem—ſtimulants are better, and 〈◊〉 more the ſtimulating antiſpaſmodics; ſuch as volatile alkali, aſafoetida, muſk, given occaſionally, and the volatile ſaline 〈◊〉 intermediately, joined with cordials, inſtead of the Polychreſt ſalt, (No. 126.)—(of theſe ſee the different formulae, 〈◊〉 page 231 to 235.)—and I have often found the ſpirit of vitriolic aether and camphor anſwer every good purpoſe we could expect from opium, without producing its diſagreeable conſequences—the warm bath in theſe caſes is beneficial.

Though it is neceſſary to have the body kept open, ſtrong 〈◊〉 always does harm—occaſionally the aloetic pill, (No. 〈◊〉 .) with or without the calomel, may be given—and as for 〈◊〉 , we ſhould rarely, if ever, have recourſe to it—if it is 〈◊〉 thought neceſſary, cupping is the beſt mode—perhaps 〈◊〉 bleeding with leeches may now and then be uſeful in 〈◊〉 local complaints of the head, or other parts where ſevere 〈◊〉 gives much uneaſineſs; but, in order to keep off an 〈◊〉 of blood, I ſhould recommend ſetons or iſſues—riding on horſeback, and that conſtantly perſevered in, is amongſt the moſt 〈◊〉 remedies—and bitters, with preparations of iron, or in 〈◊〉 caſes without them, generally muſt cloſe the cure—the 〈◊〉 waters are extremely uſeful—and, when patients have 〈◊〉 ſtrength to bear the cold bath, that may be had recourſe 〈◊〉 but care muſt be taken to proportion the coldneſs of the 〈◊〉 to the power of the conſtitution, for baths too cold are 〈◊〉 injurious—indeed in our medical conduct great nicety 〈◊〉 in theſe complicated caſes, in which we muſt 〈◊〉 , that the remedies recommended in the hyſteric and hypochondriac diſeaſe muſt be ſelected, as the complaint verges 〈◊〉 to one than the other—upon the whole, I found antiſpaſmodics and ſtimulants to be the moſt efficacious auxiliaries; 〈◊〉 former when hyſteric, the latter when hypochondriac ſymptoms were the moſt predominant; in which laſt they may be 〈◊〉 uſed; for it is aſtoniſhing in how large doſes ſtimulants 〈◊〉 be given without injury, and how very neceſſary they are 〈◊〉 produce any good effect.

div.head: § 8. INDIGESTION, CALLED DYSPEPSIA,
div.p: 〈◊〉 the Greek words dys, difficulter, and pepſis, concoctio, 〈◊〉 —If we conſider what has been ſaid of the ſtomach, and 〈◊〉 nature, (39, &c.) it will obviouſly appear, that it is liable to a variety of complaints, ſuch as inflammation, abſceſs, ulcer, 〈◊〉 of the lower orifice of the ſtomach, and a variety of 〈◊〉 —indigeſtion is then ſaid only to be conſidered as a ſymptom—indeed, it may always properly be conſidered in this 〈◊〉 ; for where there is a defect in any of the digeſtive 〈◊〉 (ſee page 72.) this complaint occurs—and if we conſider that has been advanced, when ſpeaking of pains of the ſtomach, the hyſteric, and hypochondriac diſeaſe, we may form a tolerable certain opinion of its cauſe, which generally proceeds from a WEAKNESS AND RELAXATION OF THE STOMACH AND BOWELS, and which cauſe we muſt conſider in this place.

DESCRIPTION. Under this circumſtance, there is a 〈◊〉 of appetite—nauſea—vomiting flatulent diſtenſion of the ſtomach, with eructations either ſour, rancid, or ſome other, agreeable to the nature of the imperfectly digeſted, or indigeſtible materials contained in the ſtomach—cardialgia, or heartburn, (352.)—pain alſo in the ſtomach, attended, for the 〈◊〉 part, with a coſtive habit—this diſeaſe will alſo very often produce the ſick head-ach, as proved by experience. Dr. 〈◊〉 ſays, from numerous circumſtances it is moſt clea • , 〈◊〉 this head-ach proceeds from the ſtomach, not the 〈…〉 has been the opinion of thoſe who have been ſuffered by it.

CAUSES. The remote or inducing are, too frequent over-loading the ſtomach—living upon leguminous and flatulent 〈◊〉 —ſedentary life—too violent evacuations, particularly of 〈◊〉 —taking too frequently ſtrong purging medicines; dyſentery 〈◊〉 miſcarriages; intermittents; and ſpaſmodic affections of the ſtomach and bowels. The proximate or immediate have been 〈◊〉 fled above.

CURE. The indications are, to invigorate the tone of the ſtomach, and, where wanting, to increaſe the heat—the 〈◊〉 of doing which have, in a great meaſure, been ſet down when treating of pain of the ſtomach from indigeſtion, (352, &c.) 〈◊〉 the hypochondriac diſeaſe, (512 &c.) to which we ſhall only 〈◊〉 leave to add, that cold liquids ſhould be drank in preference to thoſe which are warm, without actual warmth is neceſſary to account of the too great coldneſs of the ſtomach, and then, inſtead of tea and coffee, infuſion of roſe leaves, ſage, 〈◊〉 , or mint, may be uſed—and the preference ſhould be given to the cold bath.

If meat cannot be contained on the ſtomach, as will ſometimes be the caſe, cupping-glaſſes may be applied abo ••
〈◊〉 inches below the ſtomach, ſtimulating cataplaſms, or 〈◊〉 applied at the pit of the ſtomach—generous, rough wine 〈◊〉 be drank cold.

The mode of living ſhould be carefully attended to, 〈…〉 means will prove ineffectual—all oily ſubſtances, butter, therefore, fat meats, and meat pies, all unfermented farinaceous 〈◊〉 malt liquors, particularly ale and porter, watery and 〈◊〉 fruits, and raw vegetables, ſhould be avoided—chewing 〈…〉 or any thing which promotes too much the diſcharge of 〈◊〉 —frequent inebriation are extremely pernicious, as alſo 〈◊〉 of venery, indolence, mental uneaſineſs, or too cloſe application to intenſe ſtudy or buſineſs—for ſhould any exceſs be committed in eating, though the food ſhould be of the eaſily digeſtible
〈◊〉 , of which to the animal claſs patients ſhould chiefly adhere 〈◊〉 , moiſt air, without exerciſe, is detrimental; but cold air 〈◊〉 it is beneficial—food ſhould be often taken, and in ſmall 〈◊〉 ; but if patients will not adhere to this rule, they 〈◊〉 be confined to one kind for ſeveral days; and if vegetable moſt be indulged in, thoſe which are the moſt tender, and 〈◊〉 in their own juices, are the moſt proper.

〈◊〉 we now conſider the effects produced in the habit by this 〈◊〉 , we ſhall ſee that a vaſt variety of chronic diſeaſes 〈◊〉 to it their origin, and, therefore, on its very firſt 〈◊〉 ſhould be carefully attended to; for, if it is ſuffered to 〈◊〉 long, it is very rarely radically cured—and, indeed, I 〈◊〉 perſuaded that a great number of thoſe complaints which 〈◊〉 children born of healthful parents, in their infantile ſtate, 〈◊〉 produced from the ſame ſource, occaſioned too often by the 〈◊〉 of over-fond mothers, or the ignorance or indolence 〈◊〉 , all which I think may be prevented by adhering to 〈◊〉
•• rules laid down when treating of nurſing. With regard 〈◊〉 their cure, ſimilar modes muſt be purſued as we have laid 〈◊〉 in the diſeaſe juſt treated, appropriating the remedies to circumſtances of the caſe, and the delicacy of the frames 〈◊〉 which we have to deal.

div.head: § 9. RICKETS—RACHITIS.
div.p:
〈◊〉 Engliſh name ſeems to be a corruption of the word 〈◊〉 , probably from a ſuppoſition that this complaint 〈◊〉 its origin from ſome affection of the ſpine, as the Greek 〈◊〉
raxis, from whence rachitis is derived, means ſpine.
〈◊〉 phyſicians agree that it very ſeldom, or never, attacks 〈◊〉 the ninth month after birth, and ſeldom comes on after 〈◊〉 ſay ſix, years.

DESCRIPTION. In the beginning, the proportion of many 〈◊〉 of the body is irregular—the ſkin looſe, the belly thin, and 〈◊〉 with wind—the muſcular fleſh waſtes away, but the 〈◊〉 , wriſts, arms, knees, and feet grow large—the bones afford 〈◊〉 ſupport to the belly, and are often accompanied with ••• dneſs of the ſpine, from whence all their bodily actions 〈◊〉
• ode of moving on the ground are weak, which often 〈◊〉 in weakneſs, unwillingneſs, and diſlike of motion— 〈◊〉 children • it ſluggiſhly in the arms of their nurſes, and 〈◊〉 heavy—at that time the arteries running up the neck 〈◊〉 full—the head is large, and nods from one ſide to the 〈◊〉 owing to the incapability of the neck ſuſtaining it erect, 〈◊〉 the flaccidity of that, part their diſpoſitions are acute beyond
their age, but the breaſt is narrow, and, as it were, compreſſed from its ſides with the ſternum acuminated, and the extremities of the ribs knotty.

As the malady increaſes, a ſlow fever comes on, with 〈◊〉 cough, difficulty of breathing, and other ſymptoms, which, 〈◊〉 the moſt part, continue till death cloſes the ſcene—but this is not always the caſe—a number of theſe ſymptoms we have 〈◊〉 inſtances of continuing for a long ſeries of time, ſtill afterwards the diſeaſe ceaſes to advance, and health is reſtored, except ſome diſtortions of the limbs may remain. We 〈◊〉 have obſerved, that the opening at the top of the head, called fontanelle, and the parts where the bones join, named ſutures keep longer open, and in a greater degree, than others is an healthful ſtate; and the forehead is apt to protuberate in an uncommon manner—the children get their teeth ſlower, and much later than uſual, and thoſe which appear ſoon become black, grow looſe, and often fall out—the deſire 〈◊〉 food, and the appetite itſelf, is often quick and good; but there is frequently a looſeneſs, or a ſtrong propenſity to it—and 〈◊〉 ſometimes the diſpoſition is acute, we have ſaid, now 〈…〉 the faculties of the mind are impaired, and dullneſs and 〈◊〉 are prevalent.

Theſe ſymptoms do not all of them prevail in every patient, but more or leſs of them according to the degrees of 〈◊〉 or violence of the diſeaſe; in ſome thoſe which are more moderate, in others thoſe which are more ſevere, make 〈◊〉 appearance.

On opening thoſe who have died of this complaint, in 〈◊〉 the liver has been preternaturally large, ſcirrhous, and adhering to the midriff—the meſentery beſet with indurated 〈◊〉 , and obſtructed with the ſweatbread—in others, the lungs 〈◊〉 to the pleura, or back, and they either livid, or loaded with abſceſſes, called vomicae—in ſome the pericardium, the 〈◊〉 ſurrounding the heart, ſurcharged with ſerum—but in 〈◊〉 the brain has been found flaccid, replete in its ventricles 〈◊〉 a thin watery fluid, and the fluids themſelves through the machine in a diſſolved ſtate; the muſcular parts preternaturally ſoft and tender, and the bones capable of being cut with a knife, particularly near the places of their union.

CAUSES. The remote or inducing are, bad nurſing—ſuckling children too long—an acid produced from the milk with which the child is fed for the firſt nine months, or feeding 〈◊〉 on unfermented ferinaceous ſubſtances, and indulging too much in their uſe, particularly ſuch aliments as poſſeſs too firm a 〈◊〉 , are too viſcid and ſour, as bread not well fermented, cheeſe-cakes,
garden fruits—giving children ſour wine—living 〈◊〉 bad air, or low marſhy places—opiates too frequently and freely given—want of proper exerciſe—the habit weakened by preceding diſeaſes—a diſeaſed nurſe—and external violence.

The proximate or immediate, a torpid ſtate of the circulatory ſyſtem, and general flaccidity or relaxation of the ſolids preternaturally increaſed, by which the organs of digeſtion, aſſimilation, and nutrition, are defective in their power, and bring on a thin ſtate of fluids, and want of that matter in them which 〈◊〉 the bones called off •• i • .
CHARACTERISTIC SIGNS. A large head, ſwelling 〈◊〉 on the ſore part—tumefied knees and wriſts, depreſſed 〈◊〉 , diſtended belly, the reſt of the body waſting away.
CURE. The indications are, to increaſe the tone of the ſtomach, improve the digeſtive powers, and invigorate the ſyſtem.

In the firſt place, however, ſome of the ſymptoms are to be ••• eviated, as the ſtomach and bowels are apt to be foul, at the 〈◊〉 time the latter diſtended with wind; they ſhould be emp
•• by gentle vomits and mild purgatives—ſmall doſes of ipecacuanha, or of tartarized antimony, ſhould be given for the firſt 〈◊〉 ; and for the other, rhubarb and calomel, or Polychreſt 〈◊〉 ; rhubarb is the moſt eligible, as it is both bitter and aſtrin
•••• , therefore a good ſtimulant and tonic—the vomit may now 〈◊〉 then be repeated, as it will, by the ſhocks it gives to the ••• els and the other viſcera, of the belly, aſſiſt in taking off, or •• eventing the obſtruction and enlargement that often occur in 〈◊〉 .

The belly alſo may be rubbed with ſtimulant liniments, as 〈◊〉 liniment, or No. 182. which has been ſtrongly recommended—indeed, any of the joints which are ſwelled may be 〈◊〉 with this twice a day—and, perhaps, it will be more efficacious if it is applied after friction of the parts with a flannel 〈◊〉 the fire—ſca • e oil has alſo for this purpoſe been much 〈◊〉 , which is uſed by the inhabitants of the weſtern parts of 〈◊〉 in the following manner;—firſt, the wriſts and ankles 〈◊〉 rubbed well with oil in the evening, this immediately raiſes febrile affections for ſeveral hours; when the fever ſubſides, the •• me parts are rubbed again the night following, and repeated as long as the rubbing excites ſimilar effects—when, by rubbing theſe parts alone, not any febrile affections can be excited, the •• me proceſs is performed, and continued in the ſame manner on the knees and elbows—then afterwards down the back bones, and on the ſides—and when no fever is raiſed by this operation, a flannel ſhirt dipped into the oil is put upon the patient's body,
by which more violent febrile affections are raiſed than any of the former unctions, and is continued till the cure is completed, which commonly happens in a ſhort time.

The chief tonics employed in theſe caſes are bark and ſteel—of the former, from the nauſeouſneſs of the taſte, it is ſcarce poſſible to get down a ſufficient quantity to render it effectual—however, it may be applied externally to the wriſts, by forming the extract into plaiſter, or quilting the powder in ſoft linen, (260.) applied in theſe modes I have been informed that 〈◊〉 has proved effectual; but I ſhould prefer its being brought into contact with the coats of the ſtomach immediately, as on that, it appears to me, depends its greateſt efficacy.

Steel, as a preventive, has had its warm advocates, who, in order to be able to diſtinguiſh whether a child will become ricketty, point out the following ſymptoms:—a paleneſs and ſwelling of the countenance, and in that part of the cheeks, which ſhould be naturally red, a yellow colour approaching to that of ſulphur; in which caſe, five grains of the filings of iron, and as much rhubarb, with ten grains of ſugar, ſhould be given every morning faſting and evening—but ſhould this prove too purgative at firſt, one doſe ſhould only be given every day—after 〈◊〉 month's continuance, a keen appetite enſues, quick digeſtion and a copious flow of urine—the fullneſs of the face, and yellowneſs of the complexion, by degrees are removed, and natural countenance and firmneſs of the body gradually reſtored—and this practice, it is ſaid, has never failed of ſucceſs in any one inſtance.

Five grains of ammoniacal iron may be given twice a day 〈◊〉 a month, or longer, interpoſing occaſionally aperient doſes of rhubarb; but, in caſes of feveriſh diſpoſition, bark, with the vitriolic acid, is more eligible.

In caſes of rickets, prepared kali, (177.) half a dram diſſolved in eight ounces of bark decoction, four ounces taken every day cured a boy of ſeven years old, who has ſo much 〈◊〉 that his inferior extremities had become ſtiff and immoveable—the body flaccid, he was much worn away by a looſeneſs and conſtant ſweatings, and had five fiſtulous ulcers all diſcharging at the ſame time—in the courſe of one month from beginning to take the medicines he roſe from his bed, and walked with 〈◊〉 ſupport—the bark was then changed to madder, and in leſs 〈◊〉 four months he walked with a crutch, and by that time the 〈◊〉 were nearly healed—the watery ſolutions of kali have in 〈◊〉 ricketty people been ſucceſsful.

Strong beer, porter, and wine have been recommended; but I ſhould rather think them pernicious, the two former from
their viſcidity, and the latter from its proneneſs to become 〈◊〉 .

But the remedy moſt to be depended upon is cold bathing, or
〈◊〉 in the ſea, and is certainly the moſt powerful preventive. 〈◊〉
•• otland it has long been the practice with people of all ranks 〈◊〉 waſh their children from the time of their birth with cold 〈◊〉 ; and, from the time that they are a month old, the ſupe
•• claſs dip them entirely in cold water every morning—and, 〈◊〉 this practice has been purſued, Dr. CULLEN aſſerts, that 〈◊〉 never met with any inſtance of rickets—among the common people, though they waſh their children with cold water, they do 〈◊〉 ſo commonly practiſe immerſion; and when amongſt theſe 〈◊〉 with caſes of rickets, he preſcribes cold bathing, which is accordingly checked the progreſs of the diſeaſe, and ſeems ſometimes entirely to have cured it.

With reſpect to diet, ſtrong objections have by ſome been ſtart
••
〈◊〉 milk, and where nurſes are apt to give large quantities of a 〈◊◊〉 kind, it may certainly be detrimental, becauſe it 〈◊〉 weaken and relax the ſtomach, fill it and the bowels with 〈◊〉 humours, and alſo the machine with too great a load of wa
••• , ill-digeſted fluids, and hence favour the coming on of the 〈◊〉 ; but where the milk is of proper conſiſtence, and does 〈◊〉 appear to diſagree, it may be perſiſted in—chicken or thin 〈◊〉 broth, beef-tea with rice, or rice with cow's milk, proper
••
〈◊〉 , may be occaſionally given—and leavened bread is 〈◊〉 to the unfermented farinaceous ſubſtances, of which 〈◊〉 panada may be made, and now and then mixed with ſmall 〈◊〉 of aromatic ſpecies.
Teſtaceous powders, crabs eyes, &c. (191.) may be given by themſelves, or mixed with the food, as they are taſteleſs; for of 〈◊〉 we have accounts of their utility.

Exerciſe in theſe caſes is eſſentially neceſſary; but it ſhould 〈◊〉 the gentler ſort, and in an horizontal poſition, leſt, by 〈◊〉 upright, ſome diſtortion ſhould take place—here cradles may be of uſe, or mattreſſes laid upon ſwings, and judiciouſly 〈◊〉 to ſecure the little infant from falling out, which ſhould 〈◊〉 fixed in the open air, in ſome ſhady place, protected from 〈◊〉 too powerful force of the ſun—nurſes ſhould avoid carrying 〈◊〉 in this diſeaſe always in one arm, (126.) nor ſhould they 〈◊〉 , or toſs them up much, for the breaſt may by theſe means be greatly injured, by the preſſure of the thumb and finger on 〈◊〉 ſide the breaſt bone, from indentation or bending of the ribs inwards.

And with reſpect to ſituation, as it has been obſerved, that people who live in damp moiſt places, where the air in common
abounds too much with watery particles, are more ſubject to this diſeaſe than thoſe who live in dry airy ſituations, particularly in Holland, all ſuch ſhould be particularly avoided—and by obſerving the rules here laid down, we may be almoſt always ſucceſsful in preventing, and very often in curing this malady, if at the ſame time care is taken to preſerve cleanlineſs, which is not the leaſt uſeful rule in our conduct.

div.head: § 10. HYDROPHOBIA;
div.p: ſo called from udor, aqua, water, and phobeo, timeo, to fear, or DREAD OF WATER—this is by no means a proper appellation the term of Dr. MEAD is more characteriſtic, DUSCATAPOTIA, from dys, difficulter, difficulty, and katapino, deglutio, to ſwallow, a DIFFICULTY OF SWALLOWING for it has been obſerved, that dogs, wolves, and foxes, in which animals this malady ariſes ſpontaneouſly, have, though they have been mad, 〈◊〉 water, eat, ſwam over rivers, and run along the banks—however, as an incredible averſion to all liquids is in general the leading ſymptom, it has retained the former name—indeed, in men 〈◊〉 have been bit by dogs or wolves afflicted with this malady, the principal ſymptom is an averſion not only to water, but 〈◊〉 and light, and they extremely rarely have any deſire of 〈◊〉 . It has been differently divided by different authors—the beſt of which appear to be into that which ariſes from the 〈◊〉 of a mad animal, called therefore hydrophobia rabida, and 〈◊〉 which comes on from ſome undiſcoverable or imperceptible 〈◊〉 ſtiled ſpontanea.

DESCRIPTION. It generally firſt diſcovers itſelf by the patient's becoming languid, dull, and reſtleſs, and having 〈◊〉 dreams—ſuddenly the pains, for the moſt part, ſhoot 〈◊〉 the place where the ſkin was lacerated, all along up to 〈◊〉 throat, where it cauſes a ſenſation of ſuffocation, and a 〈◊〉 ability of ſwallowing liquids—though there is not always a dread of them attendant, yet there have been inſtances 〈◊〉 the noiſe of falling water could not be borne, it created 〈◊〉 violent agitation, much leſs the ſight.

Theſe ſpaſmodic affections of the throat, in the courſe of the diſeaſe, gradually diff • ue themſelves over the whole muſcular ſyſtem, ſimilar to what happens in tetanus, (415.)—nor is it uncommon to obſerve, in ſtrong conſtitutions, a priapiſm, 〈◊〉 even a luſtful appetite, exerting itſelf with ſome degree of violence—ſhould the wound have been healed, it begins to be affected with pain, ſwells, inflames, and diſcharges a thin, 〈◊〉
fluid—this pain is conſidered a primary invariable mark of a beginning hydrophobia.

CAUSE of the firſt ſpecies, with which we ofteneſt meet, is the virus of the mad animal abſorbed into the habit affecting immediately the nervous ſyſtem—which virus may lurk inaction in the conſtitution for fourteen, twenty-one or forty days, within which time it begins to exert its influence; and it is obſerved to do that the ſooner, in proportion as the bite is nearer to the glands, (24.) of the upper part of the throat and mouth, called ſalival.
CURE. The indications are, to endeavour to take off the ſpaſmodic ſymptoms, as in tetanus, (415.) and throw the offending poiſon out of the habit.

For which purpoſes we apply and depend upon large doſes of opium given every three or four hours—muſk alſo may be 〈◊〉 liberally—plaiſters of opium applied to the throat, and 〈◊〉 of tincture of opium and camphor—ſponges dipt in not vinegar ſhould be put to the mouth and noſtrils, that the 〈◊〉 may be kept perpetually moiſtened by its ſteams,—nor ſhould the uſe of the warm bath be omitted.

Towards the cloſe of the cure, opium may be advantageouſly 〈◊〉 with cinnibar, muſk, camphor, and aſafoetida—opiate glyſters ſhould frequently be thrown into the inteſtines; in 〈◊〉 , it ſhould be applied to every place, and by every means, 〈◊〉 expeditiouſly as poſſible, in hopes of allaying the violence of 〈◊◊〉 highly increaſed degree of nervous incitability and muſcular ſenſation—and, in order to procure an expulſion of the poiſon out of the habit, mercurial ointment rubbed into the machine, that a ſalivation may be raiſed as ſoon as poſſible, 〈◊〉 this continued for two or three weeks.

OIL has lately been recommended in this complaint, thrown into the habit by means of external frictions all over the body, thrown into the inteſtines by way of glyſter, and given by the mouth, when patients can be prevailed upon to conform to the • ode—One caſe has lately occurred, where there was every reaſon to conclude that the patient was preſerved by this method—ſea and cold bathing, with the pulvis Antilyſſus, (101.) have been greatly recommended in this diſeaſe, which have produced inſufficient.

Indeed, cold bathing appears to me, if not a dangerous, a doubtful experiment, and depends upon conſtitutional circumſtances ſolely for its utility, if 〈◊〉 has any; for without perſpiration can be increaſed by its uſe it certainly bids fair to confirm, rather than remove, the malady, by forcing the fluids too much upon the internal parts of the ſyſtem, in which caſe,
ſhould the habit not be ſtrong enough to exert an expulſive force more than adequate to the impulſive power, the poiſon would be more riveted on the nervous ſyſtem, and humourous and ſanguinary congeſtions be added to the nervous affections—indeed, CELSUS himſelf ſeems to have been aware of this, or ſome other inconvenience, ariſing from the uſe of the cold baths for he adviſes, as ſoon as the patient comes out, to be plunged into warm oil, and drink of generous wine, evidently to 〈◊〉 and increaſe the motion of the fluids towards the external parts—in theſe caſes, therefore, the warm bath and frictions appear to be the moſt proper auxiliaries to the other remedies.
This diſeaſe is ſometimes ſucceeded by inflammatory ſymptoms, in which caſe we may have recourſe to bleeding.

After patients have gone through the proper courſe of the remedies herein adviſed, ſufficient to remove the cauſe, the • cold or ſea bathing, adapted to the powers of the conſtitutions, with the uſe of tonics and ſtimulants, may doubtleſs have in uſe, in order to give ſtrength and vigour to the ſyſtem, neceſſarily debilitated by evacuants and ſedatives.

The ſecond ſpecies ariſes without any contagion being communicated, in ſome fevers—from ſome preceding diſeaſes—from the acceſſion of an epilepſy—from the bite of an epileptic patient—by the bite from people in violent fits of rage, 〈◊〉 according to the accounts of different authors—indeed an inferior degree of it will be obſervable in ſome hyſteric caſes, where, from the difficulty of ſwallowing, patients are extremely, fearful of taking liquids, nay, they cannot ſometimes be prevailed upon to make the attempt.
In all which caſes muſk and opium appear to be the remedies moſt rational, and productive of the greateſt efficacy.

When it ariſes from the bite of a mad animal, the preventive method laid down, (10 • .) ſhould be ſtrictly obſerved, which appears to be the beſt calculated to obviate the moſt dangerous and too often fatal effects of this deſtructive malady—and will CHARACTERISTIC SIGNS of which it may be uſeful 〈◊〉 cloſe the account; theſe are, a very high degree of nervous incitability, or ſuper-ſenſation, attended with a loathing, or dread of any liquid, from the difficulty of ſwallowing, 〈◊〉 a painful ſpaſmodic affection of the throat, for the moſt 〈◊〉 occaſioned by the bite of a mad animal, and ſometimes, though leſs frequently, from other accidental or inherent cauſes.

〈◊〉 this liquor add Crumbs of white Bread, 2 1-2 drams.

div.p: 〈◊〉 make 120 Pills.
DOSE. Two, night and morning, which may be gradually increaſed to four, if the ſtomach will bear them.
Syrup of Rhubarb, a ſufficient quantity.

list.item: Theſe are to be rubbed together in a glaſs, or marble mortar, gradually adding a little Syrup at a time, until the whole of the Quickſilver runs into a mucus; then, in the ſame gradual manner, add Roſe Water, 12 ounces.

div.p: DOSE. One ounce night and morning.

list.head: 171. MERCURIAL GUMMOUS PILL.
list.item: Take the Mercurial Mucus above deſcribed, and add to it Crumbs of Bread, 1-2 an ounce.

div.p: 〈◊〉 theſe into pills of ſix grains each.
DOSE. Five night and morning.

list.head: No. 172. MERCURIAL SYRUP.
list.item: Take Mercurial Mucus above deſcribed, formed with Syrup of Roſes inſtead of that of Rhubarb, and gradually add to it of the ſame Syrup four ounces and a half.

div.p: DOSE. A tea-ſpoonful morning and evening; but let the ſpoon be of Wood, Mother of Pearl, or China—and the doſe may be gradually increaſed.

list.head: 173. MEZEREON DECOCTION.
list.item: Take of the Bark of the Mezereon-root, freſh gathered, 1 ounce.
Boil theſe together to eight pints, and, towards the cloſe, add Liquorice Root bruiſed, 1 ounce.

div.p: DOSE. Half a pint twice a day.
Mix.—A fourth of this to be well rubbed only on a fourth part of the body every evening.
Mix.—

list.head: 176. MERCURIAL OINTMENT.
list.item: Oil of Lavender, a few drops.

div.p: Mix.—

list.head: 177. MERCURIAL GIRDLE.
list.item: Let theſe be well ſhook with Lemon Juice, 2 ounces.

div.p:
till all the globules ſhall ceaſe to appear, then pour off the liquor, and to the killed Quickſilver, (ſo called) let there be added half the Yolk of an Egg, and one ſcruple of Gum Tragacanth very finely powdered. This compoſition muſt be ſpread upon a flannel roller, about the breadth of three fingers, and ſufficiently
long to form a girdle to encircle the waiſt, which muſt be there worn.

list.head: 178. DECOCTION OF THE INTERIOR BARK OF THE ELM TREE.
list.item: Take the interior Bark of the Elm Tree, 4 ounces.

div.p: Let theſe be boiled to two pints, and then ſtrained.
DOSE. Half a pint twice a day.

list.head: 179. BARK AMD SASSAFRAS ELECTUARY.
list.item: Take Peruvian Bark, very finely powdered, 1 1-2 ounce.
Powder of Saſſafras Bark, 1-2 an ounce.

div.p: Syrup of Sugar, ſufficient to form an Electuary.
DOSE. Quantity of a large Nutmeg twice a day.
Mix.—

list.head: 181. VOLATILE FOETID MIXTURE.
list.item: diſſolve theſe in the Liquor of Hartſhorn, 2 drams.

div.p: Mix.—DOSE. One or two tea-ſpoonfuls occaſionally.
Mix.—

div.head: INDEX.
div.p: This not only is an Index of reference, but of explanation; as there are in the Work unavoidably ſome technical Terms, not very readily intelligible to common Readers. Where, therefore, the Words are not explained in the Body of the Work, they are in this Place. And Words marked with an Aſteriſk are referred to the Page where ſuch may be found, with the Senſe given of them. Where the letter F. is placed before the Figures, they refer to the article in ſome of the Forms of Medicine, P. 229. 403. 527.
